title: What kpop company should I audition to? - Quora

response.answer_text: To begin with you have to be honest with yourself. People will say just try it and I agree, don’t get me wrong. But you have to really and I mean really look into the company you’re wanting to go into. I’m just going be honest and list what they look for and then list some tips. I’m gonna just go into detail with the big 3 and not the others as much. Unless you are planning on doing a global auditon or a monthly one, you’d probably be doing an online one. There are four rounds technically. 1st round is online audition and you submit it and they email or call you (most likely to email you) that you passed the first round of auditioning and that they want to have a private audition with you. (Keep in mind it could take them from 2 weeks or more to respond but if they don’t respond after 2 months take it as a hint that you didn’t pass) but a girl auditioned online and didnt hear from them and gave up and then they emailed her 3 months later so don’t lose hope.2nd round private autition, you will go to the nearest city (from the stories I heard it would be either L.A. or N.Y.) MAJOR TIP HERE when they record you (you can search up on how private auditions are like, I’m not going to go into too much detail) STARE INTO THE CAMERA (this goes for global auditions too!!!) they’ll send this video to South Korea, and be reviewed and they can’t have you looking around the room, it makes you seem less confident.3rd round is where the technicality come into place, this isn’t a “official round” but in a way it is. They send your video to South Korea and the review it and then they decide if you pass the audition or not. They also see if they want you or not and they will let you know soon and will send you an email letting you know your current status (signing a contract etc)The fourth and final round is your trip to South Korea (WHICH IS NOT PAYED HY THE COMPANY) I’m assuming it’s too see if you are really serious and passionate about this. But after you get to Korea they pay for things I guess, I’m not sure because as it’s hard to find what exactly happens after you go to Korea.SM: What they look for: Looks~ this does not mean you have to look Korean or anything this just means you have to have the potentional to be pretty, as in with a little weight loss or some plastic surgery (yes SM does do SOME plastic as you can see from Yuta’s chin from NCT). But don’t let this discourage you. But if you don’t want to do plastic then don’t go here but most likely if you say no I think you’ll be okay.Figure~ SM does care about weight and they are especially seen strict with females rather than males. As you can see from Taeyeon and Wendy especially, as I remember hearing Wendy said something along the lines that she didn’t want to eat the ice cream because her manger was watching and Taeyeon scolded her manager.Talent~ They don’t really look for “talent” per day but more for the potential to be talented. Like for instance, you could not be a good dancer, singer, or model. But you have the potential to be a good one with some training and hard work here and there, you could become something more and that’s what, in my opinion, they are really looking for.Conclusion~ In the end it’s up to you whether or not you audition. But I highly recommend going to this company! Don’t believe the rumors and go with your gut instinct and the concept you think fits you best! They are usually more successful than any other company, and although the training is rigorous, you can’t expect success without any hard work and payment.Now some randome tips for SM (not in order just random: BE CONFIDENT lots of SM artist mention this A LOT so it’d be quite silly to not listen, and lots of SM artists are confident. Even if you’re a shy person at heart, fake it till ya make it.Like what Joy and Taeyeon mentioned, Joy said she said she made herself seem confident and had eyes that said “chose me” and Taeyeon said she had the look at the end of “Why” that correlates to this, that at the end of her performance she says “I did well didn’t I.”Make yourself less nervous and be charsmatic!! Make yourself seem like you have the “Idol Aurora.” But don’t try to hard!!JYP: What do they look for: Looks~ They care about looks as much as people try to deny it, they do!! They are like SM but not as strict.(I’m giving up on being organized) Jyp said he likes healthy people, so basically “idol body” ready.Also from the research I did hear that JYP has weekly weigh ins, maybe this has changed, who knows? They also in my opinion more stricter than SM. Which is ironic.JYP also looks for talent rather than looks and as the same as SM looks for the pentipnal to be great.They are likely to accept foreigners but in the end they are still a KOREA based KOREAN company, so if you complain about how they only choose Asian looking people well that’s because their market is based in ASIA. BUT THERES HOPE, the Korean companies are starting to branch into the international level, but that takes time!!! (This is for all companies!!)Also JYP has previously stated that he prefers to have trainees trained from at a young age and that he “rarely” accepts older trainees, for instance 20+ etc but that could’ve changed or there could be exceptions etc.TIPS: BE CONFIDENTBE “HEALTHY”Have the potential to be talented.(I don’t know a lot of tips because I mostly researched about SM). YG: I’ve seen in the comments YG getting a lot of love hate relationships. Yeesh. I’m going to tell you now that it’ll be extremely hard for people especially foreign people to get into YG. EXTEMELY HARD!!! Out of an estimated 4000 people with the YG Global auditions only ONE passed the auditions, and that was Lisa. Also another rumor I heard was that they only 6–8 male trainees and 9 female trainees (before Blackpink’a debut). Another thing to keep in mind is that the male and female trainees are to never meet basically. They have separate training and eating times and hardly ever interact and I think someone mentioned that the trainees and female artists are recommended not to have a lot of male friends but maybe that’s only for trainees but after debut you can interact with other males, and other male artists. And this came about I believe because of previous scandles. What they look for: Looks~ YG didn’t care about looks before but in a recent interview he said that he is now starting to pay attention to that a lot more. Figure~He, like JYP cares about this A LOT. And they wnat their artist already fit especially in auditions there won’t be much consideration (UNLESS YOU SHOW POTENTIAL BUT THIS DOES NOT MEAN THAT YOU HAVE TO LOSE HOPE) they give their artists a personal trainer and dietitian to get healthy and fit! Talent: YG cares about talent a lot, while others looks for potential, he doesn’t so much. He really looks for talented people. Tips: BE CONFIDENT THIS IS KEY FOR ALL COMPANIES!!!Have charisma (again for all companies) give off that “I can do this” or the “CHOOSE ME” vibe without making it obvious/try hard.Practice at home etc really hard and make sure you make your talent stand out.Big Hit: Someone called this company sexist and that’s completely rediculous. With what happened with GLAM (this was a co-managed group). They just never really got into the girl group game. I think I remember big hit saying that they train and deal better with males rather than females. Also they do train females from time to time (companies loan their trainees to big hit to gain experience and trianing). Also with BTS’s success (and I mean they were successful than any other group in my opinion) they possibly didn’t want to risk a sasang into the building. Who knows? But it’s their right to do so, get over it. There are many companies out there looking for talent like you, you just have to try!! That’s all the companies that I’ve done research on, mostly about the Big 3 but after seeing that comment on calling Big Hit sexist, I had to mention it. And if you have any questions be sure to DM me! I’ll respond as soon as I can, and let me know if I got any facts or anything wrong. These are all based on what I found on the internet, this does not make anything true or a postitive way of getting a successful audition but just general knowledge I’ve found that I’d like to share with you all.

To brief you on companies, primarily the one I’d personally advise, especially if you are a foreigner, is SM. I know people are probably not gonna like me for this, but let me explain. SM, assuming you have the mindset and the strength and you must REALLY want to be an idol, will take care of you, career wise and possibly financially. Essentially, you are guaranteed instant fame and success. It’s a very prestigious company. They make all kinds of music, bubble-gum pop, R&B, trap(ish), and whatnot. You’re set, if you get in, but you still have to put in 200% percent if you want to debut, so be ready to fight with bloody knuckles. YG, another prestigious company, but it is kinda on a slight roller-coaster down. It has amazing, super-talented, mostly self-producing groups (make their own music). Depending on the style of you’re group, you’re guaranteed success, as well (just not as much as SM) But trainee times are often long, and often after a kpop group has debuted, they really don’t do well in terms of promotions and can keep a kpop group stagnant, not producing any music (even if they have a huge fanbase, prime example, BlackPink, and maybe even Ikon). But they’re super-talented and they’ve produced very familiar faces in the industry that have even morphed into American music (cough Psy cough BigBang cough 2NE1 cough CL). JYP, would be the second best I’d suggest you audition for. They’ve really stepped up their game recently, boast the national girl group (TWICE), not to mention a really talented guy group (Got7), and the boss, JYP, is extremely experienced in the industry. He speaks English, if you are a foreigner, and really values competition. He’s a huge fan of produce shows and that’s often his mechanism for forming groups. Financially, I’m not sure how well they’ll cover you there, but they are on a hot-rise and are doing some really phenominal work from the industry. They’ve just debuted a new group, Stray Kids, and they’re absolutely terrific. They’re also relatively diverse (it’s a kpop company so don’t expect much outside Asia), and a lot of they’re members are from South East Asian nations. There are less popular companies other than the big three, such as Cube, Pledis, BigHit (they only accept male trainees at the moment, but on second thought, they are popular, just not as big as they’re only promoting one group and one artist as of now). I like most of the groups Cube produces, but they don’t reach the same levels as the big three. It would have to take some incredible concept to allow them to gain major traction on the charts. Pledis, is like a baby fusion between SM,YG, and maybe a little bit of JYP, with the exception that some groups don’t get the same instant fame as the big three. Pledis works you just as hard as SM, but is tending to be more open to other nationalities and ethnic origins. I personally wouldn’t recommend them, however. BigHit, they’re really isn’t much information about them, besides the fact that obviously have BTS, the biggest, internationally recognized Kpop group at the moment. The CEO, Bang PD used to work with JYP until he decided to take his own route. They apparently have a formula now, for international stardom and success they plan to use on a new boy group they want to debut (no idea when), but this is another great company that really cares for the artist, possibly the most out of all of the major companies. There are countless other companies, such as Starship, that I just don’t know enough about to give you a gist of, so I HIGHLY reccomend you shop around and do your research. Some tend to have more scandals and legal suits (specifically SM, but that doesn’t affect my opinion on them tremendously, lowkey anyone can get sued, and i wouldn’t be surprised if they got sued a lot, because of the work they do), so do watch out. And most importantly, best of luck!

JYP: JYP really focuses on talent rather visuals or nationality or race. He takes care of mental health really well, but most of the time he is the cause of the mental health. You must have a good personality over there. I’ve heard there is pretty good food there as well. Make sure you are nice and talented though if you don’t fit standards too well. some artists from there are Twice, Itzy, stray kids and Got 7 SM: I don’t think you really wanna got there. They have pretty harsh training. And they really value their visuals the most. Plus they aren’t fair to people of other nationalities. So if you aren’t Korean, that’s probably a no. They do have good promotions though and a nice fan base. But mental health goes down the hoollleeee. Some examples of Artists there are NCT, Exo, and Red Velvet. YG: mmph. I’ve heard the training there is pretty difficult according to Blackpink. They really value nice talent and they have really, really good rap and nice outfits. But, comebacks there take forever and promotions are not really that good. But YG has his Favorites, and that’s a problem. Plus they don’t protect their artists. Examples of artists over there are Treasure and Blackpink and iKON. Bighit: well bighit has been really busy these days. He’s got ILAND trainees, and is planning to debut a new boy group and some other girl group (under source I think) I think their training is pretty good. But some staff there are very disrespectful. Some are pretty nice and friendly! But bighit does protect his artists. Bighit only accepts boy trainees and some Japanese girl trainees. (I think bighit should do better with ggs tho) I will talk more about the companies under him later. Some artists that are exactly under him is TXT and BTS. Source music: I think they only except girl trainees. Acquired under big hit. I don’t know much about them but I think their managed pretty well due to being under bighit. A group from there example is Gfriend. CJ entertainment: i don’t know much about them, but I think they are pretty good due to being managed under bighit. They will debut ILAND. pledis: hahaha NO. pnation: i’ve heard that they are pretty good with trainees so I recommend! cube: they are ok, not the best though, they are pretty pick and choosy with their promotions (I like both clc and g idle) and they forgot all about clc. I’m not sure why this happened. but they are pretty small. jellyfish: I don’t know much about them, but I think they are pretty good and cool. The artists there seem pretty nice. But they do debut pretty young artists like verivery so you probably won’t get to live your childhood very long. SG: I think they are pretty new, but they seem cool! I think they’ll probably except a lot more trainees because they are so new. It their auditions have deadlines and stuff. Here’s a screenshot I took of their audition page:  Starship: Really, really small. But they do have Monsta x and cravity (I believe cravity will blow up though pretty soon) I guess you could go there if you like. KQ: also pretty small. But they have a really nice, easier ish training system which I heard is pretty cool. I would recommend. Look at ateez for example. Yuehua: don’t really go there unless you are korean or chinese. FNC: hehe. Maybe NO. They are really in the middle of a scandal and probably losing a lot of money. Pray for Mina if you pray. WM: I think they are pretty cool, it I think the diets are pretty harsh. I read that YooA had to sneak eat in the bathroom because she was so hungry. But they seem pretty sweet with oh my girl and onf. RBW: that’s a yes and a yes! They let their artists have freedom and their artists are definitely vocalists. I think they’d be great! I don’t know much about their training though. I don’t know any other companies but I recommend JYP, Maybe YG, cube, KQ, WM, starship, jellyfish, pnation and maybe bighit and source and sg (if you are a boy maybe) your very last choice should be pledis. Maybe Sm. It it depends on your qualities and specialities. byeee! good luck! You’ll never know till you try!

upvoters.user_id: Bruh What am i Doing Here

response.answer_text: You can audition for any company you like, but it really depends on your tolerance level of mistreatment. SM: You don’t want to go here. You have to go through extremely intense training. For example, trainees have to sit underwater in their underwear and hold their breath while instructors drop balls on their stomach. Even after going through all that, only 10% of trainees debut, and SM is known for not treating its artists well. Many of its artists have filed lawsuits against it. JYP: Slightly better than SM but according to one of its artists, during training before debut, instructors punish the trainees for making mistakes by hitting them and shoving them. If your pain tolerance is high I guess you could audition… YG: Probably the best company out of the Big 3 but is slacking right now. Also, its artists aren’t allowed to date. They can’t even talk to labelmates of the opposite gender. BigHit: Sexist and doesn’t accept female trainees. Pledis: Fat-shames its artists and neglects them. Managers have been seen taking away gifts given to idols for themselves. Some Pledis idols have admitted to crying every night during their time as trainees. Starship: Doesn’t promote its artists or give them legal support. Its idols could be more popular than they are now but due to lack of proper promotion, aren’t as high in the charts as they should be. One of its groups got plagiarised and it did nothing. Cube: Groups disband very often, probably due to unequal profit distribution and biased treatment to certain members. Some other companies that are unadvisable: TS EntertainmentThe Entertainment PascalMBK EntertainmentDSP MediaYou could audition for Fantagio, apparently they treat their artists really well.

It really depends on you. SM: PROS Promotes wellIf you do well you have a lot of opportunitiesBig 3 AdvantageYou become part of the SM familyCONS Get treated like trashTraining is difficultMistreatment, a lot of itJYP PROS: Good treatmentIf you’re a girl you’ll have a chance of doing wellBig 3 advantageCONS: Training is terribleThey suck at rap (unless you’re naturally good at it)If you’re a male you’ll get pretty neglectedNot too many people like the JYP music “sound”YG PROS: They care more about talentThey let you write your own music (it depends really)Always a quality performanceActually not that badCONS: They suck at promotionsthey suck at comebacksBIGHIT PROS Lots and lots of freedom“BTS” advantageThey know qualityThey know how to trainYou’re friends with everyone there (employees, other idols under the label, the CEO)*the CEO will take a picture of you if you ask him to [Taehyung, you can eat out with the CEO [BeomGyu, Kai])Write your own musicCreate your choreographyCONS: They are working on female trainees, so if you’re a girl good luck (PLUS GLOBAL)Source Music PROS Under BigHit LabelsThey know how great their idolsCONS I don’t know too much about the training system…RBW PROS FreedomTreats their idols wellIf you ask, you can chose your concept (check Solar’s vlog behind the scenes of HIP)They don’t care what you look likeAgain I don’t know too much about the company

If you want to be treated well (as best they would provide) you should look into the slightly smaller agencies as they are not so intense on their trainees. why you shouldn’t join any of the big three: SM - not a single idol likes it at all. they are the strictest of the all and looks is insanely important, your talent will not really matter e.g. Sehun from EXO isn’t really allowed to show his full potential as SM prefer his appearance. JYP - all though part of the big three they don’t do that great. idols and trainees are pushed to their absolute limits. e.g. Twice have had soo many comebacks that they are not hitting their targets, members are soo tired they need a break. also every bit of credit goes to “JYP”, Got7 had to spend so much time begging jyp to let them create their own music. YG - Comebacks? once in a blue moon, they care more about uniqueness more than talent which sure is good for applicants that aren’t actually good but it means those who have true talent don’t get their break through! basically they are not good if you actually want to show your talent through frequent comebacks. (Jennie from Blackpink said in a VLive that she was really concerned bout the length of time the company took to create music for their comeback/she didn’t think they were going to get one) I advise an agency like Cube or Starship as they have been heard of by many people yet trainees and idols are treated fairly well with some freedom

You should try auditioning for one Bighit or JYP. Bighit Pros*They give full attention to their groups in terms of promoting them and creating their new songs. There is a lot of hard work that goes into every comeback, and they don’t neglect their idols at all. They give them artistic freedom and still show success.*Big hit is a good management company. They treat their idols pretty well, and gives them good amount of attention. Bighit Con*They only technically have two groups at the moment, and TXT is already receiving a shorter stick since BTS is so huge everywhere right now. We have yet to see how it can handle promoting more artists and expanding as a company. JYP Pros* Natural, no fakeness. Artists are given freedom to be themselves on variety shows etc, real close bond with JYP himself.* JYP is good at promoting their idols for every single comeback. Every album achieves success no matter how bad it might be. Artists have a creative voice in the studio and are allowed to express themselves more openly with JYP himself.*Is very approachable. The “friendliest” in the BIG 3. Very human-like. Has good relationship with their idols. Give idols pretty good freedom(not ENTIRELY.) JYP Cons*Depends too much on one person/one idol for the functioning of the group. No individual activities are encouraged. Although songs are catchy, a lot of them sound the same and it gets repetitive.*Concept gets repetitive TOO much. Kind of flops their idol’s golden era(well they’re improving).

I think JYP. But don't miss out on SM( It's the best entertainment agency) If you would've asked me this question,I would never have said SM but in the current scenario, I think SM has really opened their doors for foreigners. And to the people who are pretty much saying that SM is obsessed with looks , I have some exceptions from you. SM chose Shindong to debut with Super Junior (We all know he's on bullier side) , Amber debuted with F(x) and wasn't forced to change herself or her styling. When Joy debut with Red Velvet she was on a chubbier side as well(This might be controversial,but I'm just comparing with other idols) Ofcourse they do give preference to looks but you might be lucky as well. (Who would miss a chance to be a part of SM family- it comes with a guarantee success). JYP- It's one those chilled out agencies who treat you literally like family and doesn't burden you much. Focuses on talent as well(Exception- Twice) but JYP lacks on promoting their older groups. It just focuses on the new group and doesn't give comeback to the older ones. So be ready with a backup after debuting under JYP. There's favouritism in JYP as well I guess (Suzy and Friends).. whereas SM hates everyone the same. YG- YG is amazing. Like totally talent. If you have it,you got it. But current scenario not that nice.. They gave Blackpink a very late comeback (they are a rookie group,they have to be active). Winner's isn't that active as well. 2NE1 disbanded. PSY and CL left. So , right now it's tough time for YG.

You are correct your chances in the kpop industry is pretty small usually interracial people in groups is frowned upon in kpop and by the people and it does lose its charm so I'm summing up all major companies I suggest you try out any of them according to your suiting all though chances you'll make it far is very less sm entertainment 60%looks 40% talent your looks play an extra role in sm although if you have a special talent they might subject u to plastic surgery . It might be the perfect company for u as they usually focus on looks and less talent. But They are especially hard on their trainees so if you can't survive harsh conditions it's not for uJyp ent - talent is more valued rather than looks and I guess they are pretty open to other trainees from other countriesYG ent-completely based on talent looks come after , only a few select trainers make it in and even a few only get a chance to debut so chances of success is lowYou can always try cube ent woolim ent Loen or pledis although chances of fame or success is less it's not impossibleKeep fighting for ur dreams and think about all outcomes after auditioning and training .im not trying to scare you intact I'm scared writing this since it can affect your decision but know the consequences of look for another path start your own YouTube channel or become famous in your own country are some other options but it completely depends on uHOPE THIS HELPED!!!!!

No one can really tell you where you should audition. No one really knows the companies. But from experience of trying out for kpop entertainments, you need to really be honest. You have a chance of making it, but there’s also a chance you won´t. If you do try out, you need to be able to live with the outcomes. If you get in, prepare for a really hard time of diet control and training. If you don´t, live with yourself and prepare to do something else. But if you want real facts, I think it depends on where you want to go and how they will treat you. From what I´ve heard, JYP is 50% based on looks rather than talent. And there are a bunch of scandels including JYP, so if you don´t want all that, don´t audition. Bighit most likely will be focusing on BTS and TXT, and I don´t think they´re taking in female trainees, only male. YG treats women wrong, and men really don´t debut much there. The smaller companies probably don´t get as much views, but go for it if you want to. SM Entertainment earns the lowest amount of profit every year, but the kpop idols there are fairly popular. And also, SM will be willing to take a chance on you, willing to take risks for you. So I auditioned for SM, and so should you. This is just my opinion, but I really hoped this helped!

I didn’t make any research on many agency other than the big3 so… SM Ent. 60% Looks 40% Talent/skill, some people said that SM is only focused on Looks/Visuals and that’s right. “Talent can be made” is one of the famous SM’s slogan. But look at the Idols whose made by SM such as BoA, H.O.T, S.E.S, Kangta, TVXQ, SJ, SNSD, and many more. SM is very strict and hard to their trainees, so if you can get it into SM, you should prepare yourself for a hard time but not the hardest. (the hardest come when you’re debuting lol). SM can accept you even if you’re not that talented or pretty if they see an ‘Idol Material’ inside you thought.JYP Ent. 70% Talent 30% Look, Some people said JYP doesn’t really care about looks but I don’t think so. JYP made many succesfull idol thought, such as WonderGirls, 2PM, Day6, TWICE (they’re succes even thought they’re kinda..), and look at StrayKids who already got the attention and popularity even thought they haven’t debuted yet. JYP known to be strict to their trainees but not as strict as SM, but yeah…YG ent. 95% Talent 5% Looks, Many people said YG really doesn’t care about looks but it’s impossible. Even if only 0.99% but they still care. YG also known to be strict to their trainee and idols, take a look at how they’re not letting iKon to meet BlackPink, they’re strict, but it’s good for the artist’s career. YG is really selective on accepting trainee and debuting idols, so the chances is kinda low.I think the agency who really openned to foreigner is JYP, even thought I’m a SM stan lolol

Reading the answers just a few comments. SM - not the monsters they’re made out to be and they care about talent a lot - if you don’t have it they won’t pick you. Looks are important but they believe raw talent can be refined. Their problems with foreigners is in the past - EXO - M members (except Lay) left because they used SM to get exposure and then launched their careers in China. My daughter is a trainee there and loves them (and since I didn’t marry a Korean she’s only 1/4 - she’s also 1/4 Chinese though and a little Japanese). She didn’t get in on her looks alone. JYP - only looking for kids and is debuting 4 groups this year, you won’t debut anytime soon. YG - treats even his stars like crap, calls the women ugly, focuses on one group, just screwed over Seungri on purpose, once made G-Dragon shave his head in atonement, generally an ass. No dating policy which broke up Jennie and Kai and just for dating he cancelled everything for her except BlackPink in the US. Made Minzy feel less then, dressed Dara hideously so she couldn’t be too pretty, abandoned Bom and made her get too much plastic surgery and basically broke up 2NE1. Wouldn’t go there unless you enjoy every aspect of your life controlled and being treated like dirt. Even after you’re famous. Everyone else, not sure yet. Small companies, little known except Pledis and no one should ever go there.

You can try going for Jellyfish ( home to VIXX and Gugudan fyi) Apparently, contracts are signed prior to training so that both company and trainees feel responsibility towards each other, which means that you have some sort of insurance? From what I heard, all expenses are paid by the company, so if the trainee gets cut off ( and wastes all the time spent on training), the company itself will also lose money. The company usually cuts off trainees with attitude problems or lack of willingness and cooperation, but if they cut a trainee off because the he/she doesn’t fit the concept of the group they are about to form, the company will connect the said trainee to another company, so they have a chance on making the cut in another band. So far the artists under Jellyfish are quite talented, and the conditions are rather reasonable. It is not a big company compared to SM, YG and JYP tho, so it’ll be a lil harder to achieve popularity, but that’s only one of the small cons. You can also try out for Bighit ( home to BTS) but I don’t think they’re planning to release a new band anytime soon.

I believe it depends on what you’re looking for. You can see my answer on If I want to audition for different companies to become an idol in Korea, can I send the same video and picture material to all of them or do I have to make new for every company? . It’s somewhat related to the Industry you should choose. Different KPOP Companies have their requirements for trainees, and you need to choose the company that suits your style. JYP Entertainment demands a good personality. If you are at least a decent person, you could audition here. You need: Talent - 60% Personality 85% SM Entertainment are known for talent. You need to be VERY good at what you do… most likely exceptional, before you can get in. Cube Entertainment…. are a weird sect though. Judging from their artists, I suppose you should have a strong fashion sense and a good perception of fashion? Well I could be wrong. The main factor still stands: Research on all the main KPOP Industries, and find what suits you about them. Thanks for the A2A! Here’s a picture of Queen Chungha for moral support. :P

Oooooo, I mean if i was auditioning , I will maybe go to SM because they’re very advanced. I mean yes you have to go through all that training and hard work but whats the point, you have to train if thats your dream that your passionate about. Either way, I suggest SM. I mean JYP is ok, though personally i don't like JYP because he's very picky and he's doesn't get happy or impressed, should I say with trainees when they put 100% effort into it or you know work hard. Here is one proof why i wouldn't suggest auditioning for JYP   This one actually broke my heart cuz JB, as a leader in GOT7, worked hard to produce those songs and when he took it to JYP, he just listened to a minute of a song, being picky in other words. AND Yg, i mean i guess Yg is good too. But based on what i heard and saw, he can get strict with trainees, you know telling them to work hard and stuff. I’m no expert but here’s some help ; SM : nononono. They treat their trainees pretty badly but the chance of you debuting is pretty high. Training is hard there and they’re strict. They focus on looks more than talent. BUT if you have a lot of talent, maybe you can try? Just note that you might’ve to do plastic surgery. JYP : Sure. Training is less strict THAN YG but have a good personality please. They focus on talent and personality. YG : Maybe? YG focuses a lot on talent and passing the audition is tough. What? Don’t believe me? In thailand, Lisa from BLACKPINK was the only one to pass the YG audition in thailand. Also, YG trainees train for years and most of them don’t debut. But you’ll get instant fame once you debut. Bighit : Again, instant fame. Idk much about the training but its worth a shot. They only accept male trainees though. Cube : Worth a shot. Cube focuses pretty much on dancing (maybe it’s a rumour) so be good at dancing, have talent. (G)I-DLE debuted recently and they had instant fame too. Don’t know if training is tough. Pledis : Don’t really know much but if your really desperate then go ahead. Starship : Training is less tough. Starship treats trainees better. Chance of debuting is also pretty high. So yes.

I suggest to go for audition in FNC Ent. You can google about the company. They produced FT Island (band), CNBlue (band), AOA (band and dance), many actress and actors (incl. Yoo Jae Suk). They’re open for any kind of talent, and FNC Ent just became the new big 3 management in Korea (replacing JYP). Good things about FNC : They didnt treat the artist so strict. There are only few rules. as long as you didnt make any bad scandal, then it’s okay for you to do whatever you want. (I know this from some interviews with the artists in that company)If you ever watched KPOP Star Hunt, FNC is one of company that wanted to find a trainee from that program.I am a BOICE (CN Blue fans) so I kinda know about their company. Of course they have some (-) points too, but I think every company always have (+) and (-). It depends on you which one that will suit you.

Just like Quora user George said, it depends on what you’re looking for. JYP is known for talent and personality and I would say also for dancing as well. SM is more on the looks than talent because they believe they can train anyone from scratch but if you’re talented, even better. (I’m not an expert, I could be wrong but this is based on my research in the past about SM.) YG is known for not looking much into looks but more talent than anything. Big Hit is a company that has gained more recognition lately due to BTS but, there’s no research that says what they look for specifically (or maybe there is and I haven’t seen it) but the only thing I can say is that as of right now, they’re only accepting male auditions. Any other K-pop entertainment companies, I know a little about but I rather not disclose because of the fact that I know too little and could be very wrong. Good luck! :)

I’ll just give a small tip of advice. Being a K-Pop Star is hard. It’s a competitive field where you can be the face of Korea one day and be the forgotten aging star the next. Trainees do hours and hours of training before doing any actual performances. Those perfect K-Pop videos? The singers and dancers practiced for weeks to just make one video. That being said, I recommend your Korean to be at least good enough to understand commands and have actual conversations. You don’t need to be super fluent, just approachable and understandable. Because you will have to deal with trainers, directors, and the media. And I have no doubt all of them will speak only Korean or very little English/Any Foreign Language. If you want to be a star, singing or rapping is a must, so I suggest you sharpen those skills up. Dancing is great and all, but from every single auditions I’ve seen (and yes, I do have friends who auditioned), those who only know how to dance fail first. Hope this helped.

You haven't tried singing but you want to try joining a professional singing group. Also, you can't even speak their language to communicate. I'm sorry but until you put more work into it your chances aren't small, they are 0. That's like saying you want to be a professional football player but you've never played football. Impossible, right? If you think looking cute and being able to dance is enough, you really need to rethink this. There is a surplus of girls that look cute and can dance. Sorry if this comes off as overly mean, but you need to be realistic.

On head of your priorities: SM: Good looks or visual, high vocals, dancing skills, more under the company rule, probably in a group of about 4-12 members, a stable fanbase, the beauty concept and a lot of fellow label mates if u debut. YG: Badass concepts mostly, rapping skills, unique voice, freedom to write and produce own songs, dancing vibes or party vibes, competitive, a good fanbase, idk till when the company supports one but overall a really good company to go for. JYP: Cute concepts maybe, good looking, understanding boss, very talented and idk so much about JYP actually.

I would go for blockberry creative, they are very efficient in training and preparing their idols (loona), they take good care of their idols (feeding them well, fly them to many locations, buy them clothes and shoes). They also gave each of the loona members their own solos before the group debut and units like allowing self representation. They companys creative vision is much more artistic than others from theories to concepts to style. Plus high quality videos and albums and appealing fan meets and other events. We love blockberry creative.

I don't think now is the time to be worrying about which company to audition for. Now is the time to take Korean classes until you are fluent, practice dancing, and get a vocal coach or learn how to rap. You'll have a higher chance of becoming an idol if you can do more than just dance. You'll also need to be able to speak Korean like a native, for obvious reasons. Keep practicing and never give up!! I believe in you!!!

If you are looking to audition for a Kpop company for a career I would probably just go for SM Town because they work hard, make good music videos, showcase your vocals and rap, and give you a chance to socialize outside training. Like Kai and Jenny got permission and SM Town let them date even with all the news going around. I hope you enjoyed my advice!

Honestly, if you are serious about getting into kpop, try out for everything. Most current trainees have been to countless auditions before getting into one and even after have been transferred to different companies dozens of times before debuting with a company.
